title: Black players feel Raheem Sterling's public defence of Bernardo Silva missed the target
text:
Raheem Sterling's defence of Bernardo Silva last weekend, following his team-mate's tweet about Benjamin Mendy, went down badly with a number of black Premier League players, who felt let down by the Manchester City forward's description of the controversial post as not racist.

Several have made their feelings clear to Kick It Out, who share their frustrations but have sympathy for Sterling's position given his relationship with Bernardo and manager Pep Guardiola, and the fact he was speaking about a nuanced subject on live television immediately after City's 3-1 win at Everton last Saturday.

Kick It Out have condemned Bernardo's tweet, which compared Mendy to a black caricature, for perpetuating racist stereotypes and will say more following the conclusion of the FA's disciplinary case against the Portugal forward, who faces a possible ban after being charged with aggravated misconduct.

Football League executives were surprised and amused by a strident contribution at their club meeting from former Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale, who made a passionate call for the owners and directors test to be strengthened in light of Bury's collapse.

Ridsdale was at last week's meeting in his role as an advisor to Preston North End, where he does not hold an official position as he is serving a seven-and-a-half-year ban from acting as a company director imposed by the Insolvency Service.

The irony of Ridsdale's barnstorming speech, given his personal circumstances, was not lost on club executives, many of whom later speculated that Ridsdale, 67, would not pass the existing owners and directors test, never mind a more robust one.

DOHA DEAL FOR ANFIELD FANS

Liverpool fans will benefit from subsidised hotels and cheap tickets if they attend December's Club World Cup in Doha.

The Qatari government are eager to attract visitors from all over the world to the country's first major test event prior to the 2022 World Cup, particularly given the poor crowds at the World Athletics Championships taking place at the Khalifa International Stadium.

They have been working with hotels to provide attractive packages and, as a result, a five-day trip, including four nights' accommodation and tickets for two matches, will be available for about £600, although that does not include flights. FIFA confirmed Sportsmail's story that Liverpool's games will take place at the Education City Stadium. Tickets go on sale this month.

Liverpool fans will benefit from subsidised hotels and cheap tickets at the Club World Cup

The Association of Football Agents' (AFA) chosen method of opposing FIFA's proposals to introduce stricter regulations, including a cap on the percentage commission they can charge on a player transfer, is unlikely to elicit much sympathy from ordinary fans struggling to cope with the rising costs of following the sport.

The AFA are building up a fighting fund prior to possibly taking legal action against FIFA and last week asked agents to make donations to an account at private wealth manager Coutts, which is the eighth oldest bank in the world and includes the Royal family among its many celebrity clients.

POCH GOES ALL 'BIG BROTHER'

Some Tottenham players have started jokingly referring to Mauricio Pochettino as 'Big Brother' due to the manager's habit of watching training sessions on the club's CCTV system. The Argentine has appeared increasingly detached from his players at the start of this campaign and, as Sportsmail revealed earlier this week, often stays inside to monitor training remotely, hence his new nickname.

Spurs players have also been speculating whether Pochettino will become a more visible presence when Amazon Prime begin filming their documentary about the club's season later this year.

authors: Matt Hughes For The Daily Mail
